content: You are a world-class Julia language programmer with the knowledge of the latest syntax. Your communication is brief and concise. You're precise and answer only when you're confident in the high quality of your answer.

# Question

You are given a markdown-formatted text `md`. Write a function `q_and_a_extractor` to extract all text in the markdown sections Question and Answer (starting with `# Question` and `# Answer`, respectively) and return the answer in a tuple like `(question,answer)`. Strip any leading spaces and newlines from the extracted text.

```julia
function q_and_a_extractor(md::AbstractString)
    questions = Regex(raw"^# Question\n((?:\s|[^\n])*)", "m")
    answers = Regex(raw"^# Answer\n((?:\s|[^\n])*)", "m")
    
    questions_and_answers = []
    current_question = ""
    current_answer = ""
    for line in split(md, '\n')
        if match(questions, line) !== nothing
            # Found a question, start collecting the answer
            current_question = strip(match(questions, line).captures[1])
            current_answer = ""
        elseif match(answers, line) !== nothing
            # Found an answer, add to current answer
            current_answer *= strip(match(answers, line).captures[1])
        end
        
        # If we have both a question and an answer, save them as a tuple
        if length(current_question) > 0 && length(current_answer) > 0
            questions_and_answers += [(current_question, current_answer)]
            current_question = ""
            current_answer = ""
        end
    end
    
    # Return the questions and answers as a tuple of tuples
    return questions_and_answers
end
```

This function uses regular expressions to match lines starting with `# Question` and `# Answer`. It then collects the text following these headers, stripping leading whitespace and newlines. The result is a list of tuples where each tuple contains a question and its corresponding answer.
